With intensive training and widespread combat experience, he adapts masterfully between different styles and weapons when faced with different opponents. He is strong and healthy, defends well against physical blows and is highly resistant to poison, disease, elemental damage and foul magic. With his sharp eyes, he spots hiding cowards.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Man, you make it hard for us to compete if you keep posting such builds

Nearly epic saves in a lvl 20 build, full tumble, dual damage types and weapon set-up's, all the combat feats you could think off and solid hp's in one build..


I am only going to make two little suggestions for your Brawler, based on his theme more than anything else.

1) Switch toughness with great fortitude, i always take toughness as a last general feat.

1) Adjust your starting stats to DEX 09 - INT 14, put those extra skill points to spellcraft for a neat +2 to all saves Vs spells. In-game you can reach 12 DEX super easily anyway, so better you have the extra skills.

* Heh, since you are partly Monk you can always wear those sweet Sun Soul boots that will have not only +2 AC compared to hardiness boots but also will handily cap your DEX to 12 all by themselves!

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Valerfor wrote:Man, you make it hard for us to compete if you keep posting such builds
Thank you!
1) Switch toughness with great fortitude, i always take toughness as a last general feat.
Do you mean that I should change the order in which I take the two feats? It is easy to change, so feel free to do so. It boils down to what you want first; better fort saves or more hitpoints.
1) Adjust your starting stats to DEX 09 - INT 14, put those extra skill points to spellcraft for a neat +2 to all saves Vs spells. In-game you can reach 12 DEX super easily anyway, so better you have the extra skills.

I am a bit on the fence about this one. Moving a stat point from dex to int gives 23 skill points, and it is normally not that hard to find +3 dex. On the other hand I am not sure if this build really needs +2 to saves vs spells. I already put 8 skillpoints in Heal. X-classing them in spellcraft will give a modified rank of 5 and +1 to saves vs spells. So I could have gone half way already without changing the stats at all.
Then again,with more skillpoints I could have x-classed Search for a much improved trap detection.
I will leave the Dex 9 - Int 14 route as a tweak to get some extra skillpoints to spend as you please.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Yup, those are more tweaks and not things that will affect the integrity of the build Mick, as i noted above:

"I am only going to make two little suggestions for your Brawler, based on his theme more than anything else."


Seeing that you went for best possible saves you could attain while have most combat feats, i suggested the INT tweak so you get better saves Vs spells, it's not that the build needs them so hard.

Same goes for toughness Vs great fortitude feat.


Again, a very solid build!

posts.author: Malazan
posts.content:
Why those two weapon choices? Could I swap one for a ranged weapon?
New player. Thanks for help

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Malazan wrote:
Why those two weapon choices?
 
Both are high-damage weapons.  The bastard is 1-10 base slashing.  The heavy flail is 1-10 base bludgeoning.  Both have the same crit range/multiplier.  The main difference is that the flail is a large weapon so much better for disarming.  The bastard can be used with a shield for added defense.
Could I swap one for a ranged weapon?
Unfortunately, no.  Check the DEX (or WIS for Zen Archery).  Pretty puny.  If this were a finessed build, then yes, one weapon could be a ranged one.  However, the largest finessable weapon is a rapier which limits the effectiveness of your disarm attempt.  Finessable two-weapon builds tend to be Arcane Archers, though there is still a sizable drop in AB potential when switching from the bow to a rapier.  Rogue or assassin sneakers also make good DEX melee/ranged hybrids.  None of these suggestions could ever be construed as fitting the category "Brawler Champion", though.

posts.author: Malazan
posts.content:
What if one just used the flail? Besides the no shield what's the downside?
You would have more feats.

Thanks for your help.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Malazan wrote:
What if one just used the flail? Besides the no shield what's the downside?
 
Don't shrug off that 3 AC like it has little effect on gameplay.  When you are being flanked badly, that additional AC can mean the difference between success and failure.  Expertise mode has its cost. You may gain 5 AC but will be missing a lot which gives the enemy more opportunities for cheap crits. 

Besides the AC advantage, the Keen property appears more often on slashing weapons than any other damage type.  In high-magic environments, you're likely to see Keen appear on totally-unrelated weapons like clubs, staves and spears, but the more realistic content would place greater value on any weapon that does slashing damage and can have its edge honed to unsurpassed sharpness.
You would have more feats.
And exactly what feats would those be?  Improved Expertise, perhaps?  Meh.  Maybe Called Shots I suppose.  Dunno. With all the others... don't think I want to be making a snap decision whether to KD, Disarm or call an arm shot in a split second.  Or perhaps bumping a few of your skills up 3 ranks?   Weigh the relative advantages of each.

The beauty of this build is that Mick recognized the all-encompassing combat potential of the class combo to allow branching out into more than one focus. 
Cleave, Expertise, IKD, ImpDisarm and even some save-boosting feats incorporated.  I'll leave Mick to sell the advantages better than I can but to me it seems obvious.

Don't forget that venturing into the unknown with a pre-established focus may not always prove as good in practice as it is on paper.  The multifocus effectively doubles the likelihood that a weapon with powerful enhancements will pop up as loot or for purchase.  I once designed an awesome DwD that was built to focus on the best 1H damage weapon around (IMO), the Dwarven Waraxe.  Problem was, there were meager pickings of that particular weapon type around the PW so I settled on a battleaxe even though I had already allocated to the waraxe focus.  *burn me beard!*

posts.author: Malazan
posts.content:
Thanks for the detailed response!

Learned a lot.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
HipRedux wrote:
I'll leave Mick to sell the advantages...
 
No need for that Hip, you already did a good job of it. :)

Even if both weapons have a base damage of 1d10,  a two hander does more damage because of the 1,5 x strenght modifier to damage. A two hander is also better at disarming, like Hip pointed out, whereas the benefit of the one hander is the AC you get from the shield.
The Bastardsword is slashing and the Heavy flail is blunt/piercing. The dual focus gives you a choice so you can omit physical damage resistances simply by swapping weapon.
